Award.AwardTitle: Permeating Sustainability and Resiliency Concepts into Civil Engineering Curricula

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Sustainable infrastructure balances economic, ecological, and societal needs by being responsive to community health and the environment. Resilient infrastructure lasts, retaining functional and structural capacity even after disastrous events. The goal of this institutional and community transformation project is to revolutionize undergraduate engineering education by integrating sustainability and resiliency (S & R) concepts throughout the Civil Engineering (CE) curriculum at Boise State University. Although the focus is on CE at Boise State, the project has significant potential broader impacts since the work can be a model for other engineering disciplines and other institutions.

Although in recent years, the CE curriculum has evolved to meet standards imposed by industry, government and accreditation organizations, these changes have typically targeted individual courses, leading to important but limited impact on the program. In this project, active learning S&R modules and appropriate design tasks will be developed and embedded in the curriculum to expose students to key S & R concepts. Combined with theory-driven, evidence-based educational research, impact on student learning will be assessed using methods grounded in the KAB framework which recognizes three distinct but interconnected aspects of individuals' responses to educational interventions: knowledge, attitudes, and behavior. Twelve CE courses are targeted for S&R infusion including Fluid Mechanics, a junior course that establishes the theoretical foundation for water flow and Civil Engineering Case Studies, a sophomore course that provides an understanding of the breadth of civil engineering design. In the latter course, the strategy to infuse S&R concepts would typically consist of the study of failed infra-structural systems constructed without proper attention to S&R. Through discussion and fact-finding, the students will acquire knowledge on how incorporating S&R considerations in the design process could have resulted in more successful designs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to revolutionize undergraduate engineering education by integrating sustainability and resiliency (S&R) concepts throughout the Civil Engineering (CE) curriculum at Boise State University. The project team developed Active Learning Modules (ALMs) and Design Tasks (DTs) for twelve strategically chosen course from CE curriculum at Boise State to achieve this goal. ALMs were developed for 1st, 2nd, and 3rd-year courses, while DTs were developed for 4th-year courses. The objective here was to introduce concepts such as life cycle analysis, uncertainty, and risk early in the curriculum so that they can be used later in the curriculum for making specific S&R assessments.

All modules and tasks were developed using theory-driven, evidence-based instructional practices that focus on carefully navigating students through the various stages of learning. Each ALM consists of: Module description, Learning Objectives, Placement suggestions, Topic description/Technical content, Assessment, and Pedagogy. This anatomy of the ALMs is maintained throughout to ensure continuity and consistency between the ALMs. Two ALMs were developed for each of the freshmen, sophomore, and junior courses selected for this project. One of the ALMs focused on concepts related to sustainability, while the other focused on resiliency. The active learning modules presented a scenario and explained how to apply S&R concepts to that scenario. Later a new but related scenario was presented, and students were asked to extend their knowledge to this scenario. This approach triggered a wealth of discussions that showed students thought processes and their journey through this process.

Design Tasks (DTs) developed for the senior-level classes required students to assess given designs' sustainability and resiliency. DTs for sustainability assessments required students to calculate carbon emissions based on the materials required for a specific design. The resiliency DTs were designed to use the sustainability DT and then alter the input values to output a probability density function of most likely results. This approach included Monte Carlo simulation techniques into the design task, effectively giving students exposure to the resiliency concepts and computational methods.

The impact on student learning was assessed using methods grounded in the KAB framework, which recognizes three distinct but interconnected aspects of individuals' responses to educational interventions: knowledge, attitudes, and behavior. Students from selected CE courses were contacted and interviewed at regular intervals throughout the project period. It was observed that the ALMs and DTs had a positive effect on student comprehension of the S&R concepts. Comparing results from the first series of student interviews to the interviews conducted towards the end of the project, a marked increase of student comprehension and understanding of S&R concepts can be identified.  

 Although the focus is on CE at Boise State, the ALMs and DTs developed in this project can have significant broader impacts since this work can be a model for other engineering disciplines and other institutions. A follow-up grant has been awarded to extend this idea of permeating S&R concepts through existing curricula into other engineering disciplines at Boise State.
